LECTURE: A graphical model is a set of graphs that show how some or all of the variables in a system change.
Graphical models include diagrams called abstractions, which leave out some of the details of a system.
An abstraction is aids in understanding the behavior of a complex system.
Some common types of graphical models include:
A flowchart is a type of graphical model that uses arrows to show how one operation or process leads to another.
A flowchart can show how a process begins, what happens during the process, and how the process ends.
A PDQ (Program, Decision, and Query) diagram is a type of graphical model that uses arrows to show the order of events.
A PDQ diagram can be used to describe a process or to explain how one or more people will do a task.
A block diagram is a type of graphical model that uses squares to represent systems or parts of systems.
A block diagram can show how a system is made up of other systems.
A state diagram is a type of graphical model that uses arrows to show how the states of a system change.
A state diagram can be used to describe the behavior of a digital logic circuit or to represent the states and transitions of a finite state machine.
A sequence diagram is a type of graphical model that uses arrows to show how objects interact over time.
A sequence diagram can be used to describe the interactions between objects in an object-oriented design.
A class diagram is a type of graphical model that uses shapes to represent objects and arrows to show how the objects interact.
A class diagram can be used to describe the structure of a computer program or to represent the classes and class methods in an object-oriented design.
A flowchart, a PDQ diagram, a block diagram, a state diagram, a sequence diagram, and a class diagram are all types of graphical models.
There are many other types of graphical models.
SOLUTION: A flowchart can show how a process begins, what happens during the process, and how the process ends.
An abstraction can be used to represent a process in a flowchart.

1. Go to the library.

An instant-runoff vote works like this:
Each voter ranks the candidates in order of preference.
The votes are counted for each candidate.
If a candidate has more than 50% of the votes, that candidate wins.
If no candidate has more than 50%, the candidate with the fewest votes is eliminated.
The votes for the eliminated candidate are then assigned to the remaining candidates based on the voters' rankings.
The votes are counted again for each candidate.

That candidate wins.

LECTURE: In an economy, resources are transformed to produce goods and services. Resources include not only natural resources, such as oil and metals, but also the human resources of a society.
Economic output, or the value of goods and services produced, is measured by GDP. GDP includes all of the goods and services produced within a country's borders.
GDP can be calculated in three ways:
1. Value added by industry: GDP can be calculated by adding up the value added by each industry. The value added by an industry is the revenue that the industry earns from selling its products, minus the cost of the inputs that the industry uses.
For example, if an oil company sells oil for $100 and it cost $25 to extract the oil, then the oil company's value added is $100 - $25 = $75.
2. Income earned by individuals: GDP can also be calculated by adding up the income that individuals earn from working. This includes income from wages, salaries, and self-employment.
For example, if a software engineer earns $50,000 in a year, that income is included in GDP.
3. Government spending: GDP can also include government spending on goods and services.
For example, if the government spends $10,000 on a road project, that spending is included in GDP.

The capital are the resources that are produced by the labor. The capital can include the machines, the buildings, and the tools that are used to produce goods and services.

For example, if a company has to pay for the pollution its activities produce, then the company will have an incentive to reduce its pollution. Consumers will also have an incentive to buy products that are produced using fewer pollutants.
Policymakers can use a variety of economic tools to design a carbon price that is effective at reducing pollution. Some of the factors they might consider include:
the level of the carbon price
the design of the carbon price (e.g., a tax or a cap-and-trade system)
how the carbon price is applied (e.g., does it apply to all companies, or just to those in a specific sector?)
how the carbon price is used (e.g., is it used to fund programs or to pay down debt?)
SOLUTION: An effective carbon price can help reduce pollution and improve environmental outcomes.
By putting a price on pollution, a carbon price incentivizes companies and consumers to make decisions that are better for the environment. For example, a carbon price can help encourage companies to switch from fossil fuels to renewable energy. It can also help consumers choose products that are produced using fewer pollutants.
To answer the question, policymakers need to consider the level of the carbon price, the design of the carbon price, how the carbon price is applied, and how the carbon price is used.

A graph with arcs but no loops is called an acyclic graph.
An acyclic graph has many useful properties. For example, the following are true for an acyclic graph:
There are no circular paths in the graph.
There is no way to follow an arc from a node to a node that is already in the node's neighborhood.
There is no way to get from a node to a node that is not in the node's neighborhood.

There are circular paths in the graph.

There is a way to get from a node to a node that is not in the node's neighborhood.
A graph with both arcs and loops is called a general graph.
A general graph has the following properties:
There are circular paths in the graph.
There is a way to follow an edge from a node to a node that is already in the node's neighborhood.
There is a way to get from a node to a node that is not in the node's neighborhood.
SOLUTION: This graph has arcs but no loops. So, it is an acyclic graph.

question:
Alice, Bob, and Claire are on the same team in a soccer match. At the start of the match, they are each assigned to a position: Alice is playing right winger, Bob is playing cheerleader, and Claire is playing striker.

(A) right winger
(B) cheerleader

model_answer:
LECTURE: In an economy, people choose how much to produce of various goods and services. These choices are based on people's preferences, which are determined by how much they like each good.
Production is costly. So, people choose to produce goods and services only up to a certain point. This point is called the maximum enjoyment level.
Because resources are costly to use, people need to decide how to use them. They need to decide which goods and services to produce.
This decision is based on the relationships between the goods and services. These relationships are called production functions.
A production function shows how many units of each good are produced when a certain number of resources are used. For example, if 2 tons of oil and 3 pounds of metal are used, the production function might show that 4 cars are produced.
SOLUTION: In this economy, the choices made by Alice, Bob, and Claire affect the production of goods and services. Each of the three people has a production function that shows how much of each good they produce when they use a certain number of resources.
At the start of the game, Alice is playing right winger, Bob is playing cheerleader, and Claire is playing striker. So, each of them is using their resources to produce a certain mix of goods and services.
After Alice and Claire trade positions, Alice is now playing striker, and Claire is now playing right winger. So, their production functions have changed.
Likewise, after Claire and Bob trade positions, Claire is now playing cheerleader, and Bob is now playing striker. So, their production functions have changed.
After Bob and Alice trade positions, Alice is now playing cheerleader, Bob is now playing striker, and Claire is now playing right winger. So, their production functions have changed.
At the end of the match, Claire is playing striker. This means that, during the match, Claire was using her resources to produce goods and services that were worth $200,000.
As a striker, Claire was not using her resources to produce any cars. So, her production function did not include cars.
